It's a shame most of their video seem to be out of youtube (and in their lame website video playing) for whatever reason, probably trying to capitalize more like small business try to profit more using less credit card companies. can't really blame them, but I still do it and kinda enjoy it. after all, it's not surprisingly fun to criticize things that don't quite work when you're not the one trying to make it through.

item.title: How can Ai help countries in need? Or developing countries. Or ourselves
item.dc:creator: @cregox Caue Rego
item.description:
@cregox wrote:

This is just a quote to this link for my answer on quora: http://qr.ae/ROw3G7

In short: it's already helping. Everyone. When you google for something, there's a huge big data Ai in place to give you the best answers. Try Siri and you'll have a glimpse of what Ai can do, and that's still a very weak Ai.

Do you need more than getting answers to any important question almost instantly? Well, the best games out there use heavy Ai - the biggest e-sport game in DOTA style is also one with the most advanced Ai systems in place. How that helps? It helps easing up our mind from the craziness around. A mindfulness technique.

And, yet, all is using Ai as smart as a bacteria. Kind of.

----

I won't get into much details, but you may be very skeptical of the last part in the second paragraph. Or even the third one. As you should. And if you are, do your homework. You'll probably find out I'm not too far off from the reality.

"How can Ai help countries in need" could be a way to reword your question. Then, which country don't need help from a superior intelligence? Why focusing only on "developing" countries? Of course there must be something we can do for everyone and most of "everyone" are in the poor region, but make no mistake - most people are poor because they prefer the simplicity of life. Capitalism isn't a zero-sum game and everyone have a choice in one way or another. There sure is misery out there, but even that is almost like a choice.

Here, this is a very geeky pseudo-code I just wrote about Life:

Here's a very geeky way of defining how life works and a clue: chance plays a bit of a role tech
[image] Chance? I just wrote this on another topic, and here I bring it as a wiki: illusion = 0 async choice: result = 0.34 * random * illusion delay 8 # seconds return result Life: born = 0.33 * random # either 0 or 1 happy = random dead = random while not dead: illusion = random # perception luck = 0.33 * random * illusion happy = (born + luck + choice) > 0.5 # is the glass half full? dead = random

In my humble opinion, the best way to use Ai in favor of our humanity is by doing what most intelligent people are already doing and heavily investing into making something like openai.com - a free, open and non profit Ai code, made by everyone, aiming at improving our mental health.

Posts: 1

Participants: 1

Read full topic
item.source: How can Ai help countries in need? Or developing countries. Or ourselves

item.title: Crowdsourcing blog posts - find a niche, outreach to experts, compile it, show it back, profit
item.dc:creator: @cregox Caue Rego
item.description:
@cregox wrote:


filter all that sand!

outreaching is where most of the work is done, and there are many tools you can use, although none is really needed. the point is making good questions to ask them on their field of expertise, so you'll have both great content to compile and an audience who will love to hear other experts feedback on that same question.

the steps are in much detail although not really so well described in this ugly link, but I promise getting aware of the core idea there is very interesting.

I haven't done it myself just yet, for it is a lot of work and, well, I couldn't set my mind to do it. But I will, and it will be awesome!

item.title: Fiction can never be as convincing as stories truly based on real facts, because of how the brain works

Not sure if this fits better under social or tech. It's sure about my perceived science.

Why novels don't convince as much as real stories? blog
( edited for more clarity ) also, for context, I wrote the post while I was very inspired and writing the 3 novel chapters that will probably not get any bigger unless people manifest themselves. since then, I've also added a buffer post about this. novels, being a creation of human imagination, and the hugely flawed human brain, have no validation on the much bigger REAL UNIVERSE, the one and only, basiux's true GOD (church of tech's god is basiux, but basiux's god is the universe). yes…

By re-reading that post, I thought it would fit better here in buffer given its size. But, instead of moving it I decided to just clarify it and link here, with a more descriptive title.

item.title: Why we need to stop looking for jobs and work on what matters
item.dc:creator: @cregox Caue Rego
item.description:
@cregox wrote:

If you're not getting any more financial results, that's probably the only sign you need to see the whole "job" culture is changing. Maybe that's the main reason why we need to change our mindsets too.

I wrote all of the below before reading a very inspiring article (in portuguese) which basically brings the same idea but made me look at it from another angle, to which I changed the title from "Why you should apply only for jobs that matter".

For one, because you'll regret if you do get a meaningless job, no matter how high the amount paid. You just will, sooner or later. Unless you are one in a gazillion that may indeed have no physiological mind issues with it (as always, words are carefully chosen here).

Also because nobody should be applying for jobs. We need to focus on working with what matters and job or talent hunting is, ideally, someone's job!

But, since we're not living yet in that ideal world, well, let's keep trying whatever works (love that flick).

This came actually from Don't know why I can't stop applying for jobs:

Don't know why I can't stop applying for jobs

[image] My heart is still with github, but it has been a while I even try applying again there, and I really could use a job now. Maybe the main difference between "could use" and "need" there is I will live if I never get a job ever again. So, while looking for a better buffer integration than IFTTT I quickly found zapier as an option on google. Then, whenever I see a great company with "we're hiring" I give it a shot (as it's hopefully evident by this very topic) and see what they're offerin…

Posts: 1

Participants: 1

Read full topic
item.source: Why we need to stop looking for jobs and work on what matters

item.title: Two weeks I haven't updated the novel... Any ideas or feedback anyone?
item.dc:creator: @cregox Caue Rego
item.description:
@cregox wrote:

This is the first release and then I announced moving it to the wiki, where it now stays.

Although I haven't touched the novel in 2 weeks, the making of have been a bit updated in just little more than 1 week and I have written 2 stories since then as well, one about traveling and the other one trying to make comedy, which should also be done in the novel.

I think I can't find any more inspiration / energy right now with the almost zero amount of feedback I'm getting - other than those astonishing and glamouring kindest words from a new friend, of course. "The guy who will make the new Matrix" he said, and he wasn't joking nor being silly.

Well, yeah, I think that sums it up. So. I'll repeat my echoing message from other posts in this abandoned ghost town... Anyone there?

I guess I just forgot about one of my latest posts!

How to tweet 101 spoiler: “Don’t tweet all about you: tweet all about them.” tech
[image] Random pic, a view from chapito. A short guide to social media in general (even while focused on twitter) for newbies like me. This is just my humble opinion main points summed up from yet another great buffer post: A good bio sells. Be descriptive. Add: accuracy. One professional description. excitement. One word that is not boring. target. One niche descriptor. flattering. One accomplishment. human element. Such as 01 hobby. intrigue. One interesting fact or feature about yourse…

item.title: David Bowie died and I envy his life a whole lot
item.dc:creator: @cregox Caue Rego
item.description:
@cregox wrote:


gif made from a random tweet.

twitter.com

Caue C M Rego (cauerego)

Sad? Only knew him from labyrinth. He had a legen insanely fulfilling life, died in a dary age. To me it's envy. :) twitter.com/elonmusk/statu…
10:18 AM - 11 Jan 2016

That triggered me to do some wikipedia reading, all on the mobile. IMHO, he was luckily born in an easy place to live, enjoyed financial freedom for ever, plus quickly figured out what sex and religion is all about in his heart - i.e. he wasn't tainted by all his freedom and did manage to set his mind in the right place - unlike most people especially in famous positions as his.

Dying 2 days after being 69 on top of it all? Such a meaningful number with the most common cause of death in the recent days? If I were living his life and had to choose a time and place to die, I couldn't do any better.


(youtube link first posted on the daily wtf)

Posts: 1

Participants: 1
